questions.text: An unknown male was brought to the emergency department with burns from his hands, chest and face. The skin was sodden and bleached with the presence of a red line. There were vesicles on the burnt area. What is the probable cause of burns?
questions.solution:
• Cause of Burns: The characteristics of the burns suggest moist heat burn.
    • Sodden and Bleached Skin: Indicates exposure to moisture or steam.
    • Red Line and Vesicles: Typical signs of moist heat burns.

(Why Not Others):

  • (a): Dry heat burns result in dry, wrinkled skin, often charred; does not match the description.
  • (c): Chemical burns usually present with corroded skin and distinctive colorations, not typically bleached or sodden.
  • (d): Radiation burns do not cause moist appearances; they usually result in dry, erythematous skin.

Key Takeaway:

Moist heat burns typically result from steam or hot liquids, leading to characteristic sodden and bleached skin with the presence of vesicles and red lines.

questions.text: Identify the injury sustained during road traffic accident by a pedestrian.
questions.solution:
• Injury Type: The injury sustained during a road traffic accident by a pedestrian is a bumper fracture.
    • Characteristics:
      • Comminuted wedge-shaped fracture of the tibia.
      • Forward displacement of bony fragments.
      • Base of the triangular fracture indicates the impact site, apex points in the direction of the vehicle.

(Why Not Others):

  • (a): Gutter fracture: Refers to a skull fracture, not relevant to pedestrian injuries.
  • (b): Ping pong fracture: A type of skull fracture typically seen in children.
  • (d): Hinge fracture: Also, a skull fracture, related to the base of the skull.

Key Takeaway:

Bumper fractures are indicative of pedestrian injuries during road traffic accidents, characterized by specific fracture patterns linked to vehicle impact.

choices.text: They are superficial cuts of skin by tempered glass fragments
Produced when the windshield of a car shatter
Fragments of tempered glass embedded in the wound may be seen
Help to determine the position of pedestrian and side of impact

questions.text: Which of the following statement about Dicing injuries is FALSE?
questions.solution:
• Dicing Injuries: These are superficial cuts caused by tempered glass fragments during car crashes.
    • Characteristics:
      • Type: Linear, right-angled, or V-shaped lacerations.
      • Location: Commonly on the face, forehead, and arms, typically on the driver's side or passenger's side.

(Why Not Others):

  • (a): True. Dicing injuries are indeed superficial cuts caused by tempered glass.
  • (b): True. They are produced when the windshield of a car shatter.
  • (c): True. Fragments of tempered glass can be embedded in the wounds.

Key Takeaway:

Dicing injuries indicate the position of victims inside a vehicle during a crash, not pedestrians outside, highlighting the impact of tempered glass in vehicle collisions.

questions.text:
Choose the correct option about whiplash injury.
(i) It is due to acceleration mechanism of energy transfer to the neck
(ii) Commonly seen in road traffic accidents
(iii) Less common in driver than passengers
(iv) Lumber spine is commonly involved
questions.solution:
• Whiplash Injury Mechanism:
    • Caused by acceleration-deceleration forces affecting the neck.
    • Typically involves hyperextension and hyperflexion of the cervical spine during rear-end collisions.
  • Common Scenarios:
    • Frequently occurs in road traffic accidents, especially during rear-end impacts.
    • Less common in driver than passengers because, the driver will be more alert at the time of impact and he stabilises his neck.
  • Injury Characteristics:
    • Can lead to both bony injuries (fractures) and soft tissue injuries (ligaments, muscles).
    • Lumbar spine involvement is rare; primarily affects the cervical spine.

Why Not Others :

  • Option a (i & iv):
    • Incorrect because while (i) is true, (iv) is false; whiplash primarily affects the cervical spine, not the lumbar spine.
  • Option b (i & iii):
    • Incorrect because (i) is true but does not directly indicate common scenarios, and (iii) is correct but does not include the important aspect of its prevalence in accidents.
  • Option d (ii & iv):
    • Incorrect because (ii) is true, but (iv) is false; the lumbar spine is not commonly involved in whiplash injuries.

Key Takeaways:

  • Whiplash is mainly associated with the neck and cervical spine injuries.
  • It is predominantly seen in occupants than drivers during road accidents.

questions.text: When a motorcyclist drives under the rear of a truck resulting in head injuries, it is called
questions.solution:
• Definition: Tail-gating refers to driving closely behind another vehicle, which can lead to accidents when the driver fails to maintain a safe distance.
  • Consequences: This can result in severe head injuries or even decapitation when the motorcyclist drives under a truck.

Why Not Others :

  • b. Over running: This term does not specifically relate to the scenario described and typically refers to exceeding speed limits without the context of a collision.
  • c. Over speeding: While this involves driving at excessive speeds, it does not specifically describe the act of driving under a truck.
  • d. Bunking: This term is not relevant to the context of driving or accidents; it typically refers to skipping or avoiding responsibility.

Key Takeaways:

  • Tail-gating can lead to dangerous situations, especially with larger vehicles.
  • Maintaining a safe distance is crucial for preventing accidents.

questions.text: Chance fracture is the term used for ___
questions.solution:
• Definition:
    • Chance fractures (also known as seat belt fractures) are flexion-distraction injuries of the spine.
    • They involve all three spinal columns (anterior, middle, and posterior), making them unstable injuries.
    • Commonly occur at the thoracolumbar junction.
  • Associated Injuries:
    • High association with intra-abdominal injuries (e.g., bowel perforations).
    • Seat belt syndrome: Involves a seat belt mark, intra-abdominal organ injury, and thoracolumbar vertebral fractures.

Why Not Others:

  • b. Cervical fracture:
    • Involves the cervical spine, not the thoracolumbar region.
  • c. Knuckle fracture:
    • Refers to fractures of the metacarpals, unrelated to spinal injuries.
  • d. Bumper fracture:
    • Typically refers to specific injuries related to vehicle impacts, not to the thoracolumbar region.

Key Takeaways

  • Chance fractures are serious and unstable injuries commonly associated with seat belt use during accidents.
  • Always consider the potential for intra-abdominal injuries in these cases.

questions.text:
Choose the correct option of feet first impact during fall is
(i) Fracture of calcaneus or ankle joint
(ii) Comminuted fracture of skull
(iii) Ring fracture of skull
(iv) Traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage
questions.solution:
• Feet-First Impacts:
    • Fracture of Calcaneus or Ankle Joint:
      • Common due to direct impact.
    • Ring Fracture of Skull:
      • Occurs from forces driving the spinal column upward into the cranial cavity.
  • Injuries:
    • May also include pelvic trauma and longitudinal tears in the inguinal regions.
  • Additional Considerations:
    • Palmar skin tears and open comminuted fractures of the wrists and knees are seen in attempts to cushion the impact.

Why Not Others:

  • a. (i) & (iv) are correct:
    • Incorrect; traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage is more associated with head-first impacts.
  • c. (ii) & (iii) are correct:
    • Incorrect; while ring fractures occur, comminuted skull fractures are not typical in feet-first falls.
  • d. (ii) & (iv) are correct:
    • Incorrect; both statements are more aligned with head-first impacts rather than feet-first.

Key Takeaways

  • Feet-first impacts typically lead to fractures of the ankle and calcaneus, along with potential ring fractures of the skull.

choices.text: Fracture of lateral condyle of tibia

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT the component of Waddell's triad?
questions.solution:
• Waddell's Triad:
    • A classic pattern of injury seen in pedestrian children struck by motor vehicles.
    • Components:
      • Fractured femoral shaft: Common injury in this triad.
      • Intra-thoracic/intra-abdominal injuries: Significant injuries often associated with the impact.
      • Contralateral head injury: Occurs when the child is thrown to the ground after the initial impact.
  • Mechanism of Injury:
    • Initial impact causes injuries to the pelvis and femur instead of the knees and tibias, followed by injuries to the chest and abdomen (from grill, fender, or hood).
    • The child is then thrown to the ground, sustaining injuries to the opposite side of the head.

Why Not Others:

  • a. Fracture of femur:
    Correct; it is a component of Waddell's triad.
  • b. Intra-thoracic/intra-abdominal injuries:
    Correct; it is a component of Waddell's triad.
  • c. Contralateral head injury:
    Correct; it is a component of Waddell's triad.

Key Takeaways

  • Waddell's triad includes a fractured femur, intra-thoracic/intra-abdominal injuries, and contralateral head injury, but not a fracture of the lateral condyle of the tibia.

questions.text: Ewing's postulate helps to relate causal relationship between
questions.solution:
• Causal Link: Ewing's postulate establishes a connection between trauma and the subsequent development of tumors.
  • Examples:
    • Development of osteogenic sarcoma or osteoclastoma after injury.
    • Malignancy arising in burn scars or near chronic osteomyelitic sinuses.
  • Mechanism: Trauma disrupts tissues, potentially activating pre-existing tumors to grow more aggressively.

Ewing's Postulates Criteria

  1. Normal Tumor Site: The tumor site must have been normal before the injury.
  2. Proven Trauma: There must be undeniable and adequate trauma that disrupted continuity.
  3. Timely Development: The tumor must follow the injury within a reasonable time frame (3-4 weeks to a maximum of 3 years).
  4. Origin of Tumor: The tumor should originate in the injured part of the body.
  5. Histological Type: The tumor must be of a histological type that can arise from the disrupted cells due to trauma.

Why Not Others

  • a. Trauma and Myocardial infarction: Not relevant; myocardial infarction is primarily related to vascular issues, not directly to trauma.
  • c. Trauma and Epilepsy: While trauma can cause seizures, it does not establish a neoplastic relationship.
  • d. Trauma and Death: Death can result from various causes, but it doesn't imply a causal relationship with neoplasia.

Key Takeaways

Ewing's postulate emphasizes the potential link between trauma and the development of neoplasia, focusing on specific criteria to establish this relationship.

questions.text: Punishment for grievous hurt is prescribed in which section of BNS?
questions.solution:
• S. 115 BNS: Pertains to voluntarily causing hurt (similar to S. 321, 323 I.P.C).
  • S. 116 BNS: Specifically addresses grievous hurt (corresponds to S. 320, I.P.C).
  • S. 117 BNS: Relates to voluntarily causing grievous hurt (aligned with S. 322, 325, I.P.C).
  • S. 118 BNS: Concerns causing hurt or grievous hurt using dangerous weapons or means (linked to S. 324, 326, I.P.C).

Dangerous Weapons or Means

  • Includes any instrument for shooting, stabbing, or cutting.
  • Covers heated substances, poisons, corrosive substances, explosives, and harmful substances.
  • Encompasses any animal used in a way likely to cause death.

Why Not Others

  • a. S. 115: Deals with general hurt, not specifically grievous hurt.
  • c. S. 117: Focuses on the act of voluntarily causing grievous hurt, not the definition or punishment for grievous hurt itself.
  • d. S. 118: Addresses the use of dangerous weapons, which is a subset of grievous hurt cases.

Key Takeaways:

  • S. 116 clearly defines and prescribes punishment for grievous hurt under the BNS.

Reference:https://www.mha.gov.in/sites/default/files/250883_english_01042024.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT included in the triad of Fat Embolism Syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Fat Embolism Syndrome Triad:
    • Cutaneous Dysfunction: Includes petechial hemorrhages, especially in the axillae and neck.
    • Neurological Dysfunction: Can manifest as confusion, agitation, or more severe changes due to cerebral fat embolism.
    • Respiratory Dysfunction: Presents with respiratory distress, hypoxemia, and bilateral patchy infiltrates on chest X-ray.
  • Fat Emboli Dynamics:
    • Occur in patients with long bone fractures; only some develop systemic dysfunction.
    • A small volume of free fat (12-120 ml) can lead to embolic death.
    • Symptoms can start 8-20 hours post-injury, with death possible within 10 days but potentially delayed up to 3 weeks.

Why Not Others

  • a. Cutaneous Dysfunction: A key component of the syndrome with visible symptoms.
  • b. Neurological Dysfunction: Integral to the diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.
  • c. Respiratory Dysfunction: Critical for identifying the syndrome and involves serious complications.

Key Takeaways

  • Bone marrow dysfunction is NOT part of the triad for Fat Embolism Syndrome, which focuses on cutaneous, neurological, and respiratory dysfunctions.

questions.text: Choose the correct clause of section 116 BNS applicable to the injury shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Clauses of S.116 BNS (S.320 IPC):

  1. Emasculation: Removal of male reproductive organs.
  2. Permanent Privation of the Sight of Either Eye: Loss of vision in one or both eyes.
  3. Permanent Privation of the Hearing of Either Ear: Loss of hearing in one or both ears.
  4. Privation of Any Member or Joint: Loss of a limb or joint function.
  5. Destruction or Permanent Impairing of the Powers of Any Member or Joint: Significant loss of function in a limb or joint.
  6. Permanent Disfiguration of the Head or Face: Lasting disfigurement affecting appearance.
  7. Fracture or Dislocation of a Bone or Tooth: Involves breaking or dislocating bones or teeth.
  8. Any Hurt Which Endangers Life: Injuries that may lead to death or severe pain lasting over 15 days.
  • Clause 7 specifically addresses injuries resulting in fractures or dislocations, making it applicable to the injury depicted in the image.

Why Not Others

  • a. Clause 1: Not relevant as it pertains to emasculation.
  • b. Clause 3: Pertains to hearing loss, not applicable here.
  • c. Clause 5: Concerns impairment rather than a specific fracture or dislocation.

Key Takeaways

  • Clause 7 applies to fractures or dislocations, while the other clauses cover different types of injuries or impairments.

https://www.mha.gov.in/sites/default/files/250883_english_01042024.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication of Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) of legs?
questions.solution:
• Pulmonary Embolism (PE):
    • Prevalence: Occurs in 60-80% of DVT patients.
    • Symptoms: Abrupt onset of pleuritic chest pain, shortness of breath, and palpitations.
    • Severe Cases: Can lead to collapse, hypotension, and sudden death.
    • Diagnosis: CT angiography is the gold standard; autopsy may show saddle pulmonary embolism.
  • Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC):
    • Causes: Trauma, infection, and acute events.
    • Mechanism: Abnormal coagulation activation leads to clotting and bleeding issues.
  • Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS):
    • Causes: Heavy thoracic impacts, toxins, and aspiration.
    • Effects: Diffuse alveolar damage; lungs become stiff and edematous.
  • Crush Syndrome:
    • Causes: Prolonged pressure on muscles (e.g., accidents).
    • Manifestations: Rhabdomyolysis, myoglobinuria, and acute renal failure.

Why Not Others

  • a. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation: More related to acute trauma and infections, not primarily DVT.
  • b. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome: Not directly caused by DVT but by severe thoracic injuries or other conditions.
  • c. Crush Syndrome: Involves muscle injury due to external pressure; unrelated to DVT complications.

Key Takeaways

  • Pulmonary embolism is the leading complication of DVT, with significant morbidity and mortality. Other options relate to different conditions and complications.

choices.text: The ligature mark will produce a inverted 'V' shaped mark on neck
The abrasion is not a type of pressure abrasion
The autopsy findings may show neck muscles bruising
Congested face with profuse petechial haemorrhages

questions.text: Observe the image and choose the correct options.
questions.solution:
• a. The ligature mark will produce a inverted 'V' shaped mark on neck:
    • Correct: In cases of hanging, the ligature mark is typically inverted 'V' shaped due to extension of ligature material downward on both sidesfrom the knot above The apex of 'V' may be missing).
  • b. The abrasion is not a type of pressure abrasion:
    • Incorrect: The abrasion observed in hanging is a type of pressure abrasion, resulting from the tightness of the ligature against the skin.
  • c. The autopsy findings may show neck muscles bruising:
    • Incorrect: Neck muscle bruising is more commonly associated with strangulation, not hanging.
  • d. Congested face with profuse petechial haemorrhages:
    • Incorrect: In hanging, the face is usually pale, and petechiae are less common compared to strangulation.

Why Not Others:

  • b. The abrasion is not a type of pressure abrasion: incorrect : The abrasion observed in hanging is a type of pressure abrasion, resulting from the tightness of the ligature against the skin.
  • c. The autopsy findings may show neck muscles bruising: Incorrect; bruising is typical in strangulation.
  • d. Congested face with profuse petechial haemorrhages: Incorrect; the face is pale in hanging, and petechiae are less common.

Key Takeaways:

  • In hanging, the ligature mark is V-shaped, and abrasions are pressure-related, while bruising of neck muscles and facial congestion with petechiae are characteristic of strangulation.

choices.text: Bruising of neck muscles may be seen
Intima of carotid arteries is damaged

questions.text: Choose the INCORRECT option about the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows death due to ligature strangulation.

  • a. Bruising of neck muscles may be seen:
    • True. Common in strangulation due to significant force applied.
  • b. Subcutaneous tissue can be ecchymosed:
    • True. Ecchymosis is typical in strangulation due to vascular rupture.
  • c. Intima of carotid arteries is damaged:
    • Incorrect. Damage to the intima of carotid arteries is associated with hanging and throttling, not in ligature strangulation.
  • d. Thyroid fracture is likely:
    • True. Thyroid fractures can occur during strangulation due to the force applied to the neck.

Key Takeaways:

  • Strangulation: Bruising of neck muscles, subcutaneous ecchymosis, and possible thyroid fractures are common findings.
  • Hanging: Primarily involves the ligature mark and can cause intimal damage to carotid arteries, making option c the incorrect statement in this context.

https://www.jems.com/patient-care/initial-findings-in-strangulation-injury-aren-t-indicative-of-outcome/

choices.text: Reflex cardiac arrest due to vagal stimulation

questions.text: The cause of death in Cafe coronary is
questions.solution:
• Reflex cardiac arrest due to vagal stimulation:

'CAFÉ CORONARY' SYNDROME':

  • A popular term 'cafe coronary' was coined by Dr. Roger Haugen, Medical Examiner of Broward County, Florida for such impaction of food in the respiratory passage.
  • The victim may be observed slumping over the dining table or collapsing suddenly while walking across the room after having meals, with no signs of respiratory distress or any of the 'classic signs of asphyxia'.
  • The original series of deaths involved well-nourished businessmen dying suddenly and unexpectedly in restaurants and cafes, while sitting or shortly after sitting in their chairs, as if they died of heart attack. Hence, the name 'cafe coronary'.
  • However, autopsy usually reveals a bolus of food in the pharynx or larynx. Many cases have been reported where the victim was merely seen dead while sitting or just after sitting in a chair, the mode of death probably being cardiac arrest due to overactivity of parasympathetic nervous system through the stimulation of branches of vagus nerve supplying the laryngeal and/or pharyngeal mucosa.
  • Fairly high level of alcohol has been found in most cases of cafe coronary deaths. The suppression of gag reflex due to alcohol or drugs makes the individual susceptible to this calamity.
  • Senile persons in retirement homes and mentally retarded children in institutions are also vulnerable.

Why Not Others:

  • b. Myocardial infarction:
    • Incorrect; while symptoms may mimic a heart attack, the actual cause is choking.
  • c. Caffeine overdose:
    • Incorrect; this condition is unrelated to caffeine and its effects.
  • d. Alcohol toxicity:
    • Incorrect; while alcohol may impair reflexes, it is not the direct cause of death in Cafe coronary.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cafe Coronary results primarily in intoxicated individuals, where a bolus of food in the pharynx or larynx stimulates the laryngeal nerve endings (Vagus) leading to reflex cardiac arrest.

questions.text: What is your opinion about the probable cause of death on examination of froth depicted in the given image.
questions.solution:
• Drowning:
    • Characteristic Finding: Presence of fine, copious white froth resembling "shaving lather" at the mouth and nostrils.
    • Froth Composition: The foam consists of fine bubbles that do not collapse upon touch and may reappear when pressure is applied to the chest.
  • Other Causes:
    • Hanging: Characterized by dribbling of saliva; froth is minimal and not like that seen in drowning.
    • Strangulation: Involves blood and mucus-tinged froth, not copious like in drowning.
    • Poisoning: The froth is less abundant and lacks the specific characteristics of drowning froth.

Why Not Others:

  • a. Hanging:
    • Incorrect; hanging typically does not present with the copious froth characteristic of drowning.
  • b. Strangulation:
    • Incorrect; strangulation presents with different types of froth and is not typically copious.
  • d. Poisoning:
    • Incorrect; poisoning-related froth is usually less abundant and different in appearance.

Key Takeaways:

  • The presence of copious, fine, white froth is indicative of drowning, distinguishing it from other causes like hanging, strangulation, and poisoning.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2665910721000207

https://purposehealingcenter.com/what-drugs-cause-foaming-at-the-mouth/

choices.text: Ballooned but light in weight compared to saltwater drowning.
Pale-pink or pale grey in colour
Retain their normal shape and do not collapse when they are removed from the chest
On Section, crepitus is not heard

questions.text: Choose the incorrect response about lungs in freshwater drowning
questions.solution:
• Freshwater Drowning:
    • Size and Weight:
      • Ballooned but Light: Lungs are inflated due to water intake but are lighter in weight compared to saltwater drowning.
    • Colour:
      • Pale-Pink or Pale Grey: The color of the lungs in freshwater drowning tends to be pale-pink or pale grey.
    • Shape After Removal:
      • Retain Normal Shape: The lungs retain their shape and do not collapse when removed from the chest.
    • Crepitus:
      • Heard on Section: In freshwater drowning, crepitus is typically present upon section.

Key Takeaways:

  • In freshwater drowning, the lungs are ballooned, light, and retain their shape, with a color typically described as pale-pink or pale grey.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of death in Burking?
questions.solution:
• Burking:
    • A method of homicidal smothering and traumatic asphyxia.
    • Involves sitting or kneeling on the chest of the victim while obstructing their nose and mouth.
    • Historically associated with William Burke and William Hare, who murdered 16 people for anatomical purposes.
    • The victim was incapacitated (often through alcohol), and then asphyxiated.
  • Why Not Others:
    • a. Choking:
      • Refers to an obstruction of the airway, not applicable to the method of Burking.
    • b. Reflex vagal inhibition:
      • While this can lead to cardiac arrest, it is not the primary cause in Burking.
    • c. Laryngeal spasm:
      • This can occur in drowning but is not typical in cases of Burking.

Key Takeaways:

  • The cause of death in Burking is primarily due to traumatic asphyxia with smothering, where the victim is forcibly asphyxiated through pressure on the chest and obstruction of the airways.

choices.text: Absence of any form of sexual activity
History of depression or suicidal ideation

questions.text: Which of the following is the feature of Autoerotic asphyxia?
questions.solution:
• Autoerotic Asphyxia:
    • A paraphilia where sexual arousal and orgasm are achieved through self-induced asphyxia, stopping short of loss of consciousness.
    • Involves partial asphyxia from pressure on the carotid vessels or airway obstruction, leading to cerebral ischemia and potential erotic hallucinations.
    • The mechanism allows for self-release, but accidental death can occur if the victim is unable to free themselves.

Why Not Others:

  • a. Absence of any form of sexual activity:
    • This is incorrect as the practice specifically involves sexual activity.
  • c. History of depression or suicidal ideation:
    • While some individuals may have these histories, it is not a defining feature of autoerotic asphyxia.
  • d. No association with other paraphilias:
    • Autoerotic asphyxia is often associated with other forms of paraphilia, such as masochism and transvestism.

Key Takeaways:

  • Autoerotic asphyxia is characterized by the presence of a rescue mechanism, allowing individuals to control the degree of asphyxia while engaging in sexual activity, often resulting in accidental death when control is lost.

choices.text: A magistrate inquiry has to be conducted within 12 hours of occurrence.
The video recording of the postmortem examination is to be done.
A total of 20-25 coloured photographs of the whole body should be taken and some photographs should be without removing the clothes.
All reports viz. Postmortem, videography and magisterial inquiry reports must be sent to the Commission within 2 months of the incident.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about National Human Rights Commission guidelines in case of custodial deaths?
questions.solution:
• Magistrate Inquiry Timing:
    • The correct timeframe for conducting a magistrate inquiry is within 24 hours, not 12 hours.
  • Video Recording of Postmortem:
    • Required as part of the guidelines to ensure transparency and documentation.
  • Photographic Evidence:
    • Taking 20-25 coloured photographs, including some with clothes intact, is mandated for thorough documentation.
  • Reporting Timeline:
    • All relevant reports must be submitted to the Commission within 2 months after the incident.

Why Not Others:

  • b. The video recording of the postmortem examination is to be done:
    • True; it is a requirement for documentation.
  • c. A total of 20-25 coloured photographs of the whole body should be taken and some photographs should be without removing the clothes:
    • True; this is part of the guidelines for thorough evidence collection.
  • d. All reports viz. Postmortem, videography and magisterial inquiry reports must be sent to the Commission within 2 months of the incident:
    • True; this is mandated by the guidelines.

Key Takeaways:

  • The incorrect statement regarding the timing of the magistrate inquiry highlights the importance of following established protocols to ensure proper investigation in custodial deaths, which must be initiated within 24 hours rather than 12 hours.

questions.text: Repeated beating on soles by blunt objects is called
questions.solution:
• Falanga/bastinado:
    • A method of physical torture where repeated beating on the soles of the feet is performed using blunt objects like sticks.
  • Telefono:
    • Involves repeated slapping on both ears with open hands, leading to hearing damage.
  • El quirofano:
    • Refers to beating on the abdomen while the victim is lying on a table with the upper body unsupported.
  • Chepuwa:
    • Involves pressing the thigh placed between two wooden rods, causing intense pain.

Why Not Others:

  • a. Telefono:
    • Incorrect as it refers to slapping the ears, not beating the soles.
  • c. El quirofano:
    • Incorrect as it involves beating the abdomen.
  • d. Chepuwa:
    • Incorrect as it involves pressure on the thigh, not the feet.

Key Takeaways:

  • Falanga/bastinado is specifically linked to beating the soles with blunt objects, commonly used in torture practices.
